quote: May I help you? You might as well    come in.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: I'm sorry to bother you, it's just    that...        I... I've been...
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: You're hurt.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: I must've scraped myself on a branch.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: That's what happens when you go    tromping around the bayous in the    middle of the night.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Go warm up by the fire. I have a    first aid kit around here    somewhere...        Now where is it... ?
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: So... what are you doing out here,    anyway?
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: I'm a writer...        -- at least, I want to be.    (decides to come out     with it)    And the truth is... I was looking    for you...
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Oh?
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: You are Jake Sisko... the writer?
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: I can't believe I'm really here.    Talking to you. You're my    favorite author... of all time.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: You should read more...
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: I mean it. Your books... they're    so insightful...
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: I'm glad you like them.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: There. Good as new.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Thank you.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: I didn't realize people still read     my books.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Of course they do. A friend     recommended Anslem to me and I     read it straight through, twice in     one night.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Twice in one night... ?
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: It made me want to read everything     you'd ever written, but when I     looked, all I could find were your     "Collected Stories." I couldn't     believe it.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: I'd finally found someone whose     writing I really admired, and he'd     only published two books.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Not much to show for a life's     work, is it? I'm going to get us     some tea.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: I savored those stories, read them     slowly, one each day. And when I     was finished, I wished I hadn't     read them at all.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: So that I could read them again...     like it was the first time.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: There's only one "first time" for     everything, isn't there?          And only one last time, too. You     think about that when you get to     be my age. That today might be     the last time you... sit in a     favorite chair... watch the rain     fall... enjoy a cup of tea.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Can I ask you something... ?
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Why did you stop writing?
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: I lost my favorite pen... just     couldn't seem to get any work done     without it.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: You're joking.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: You weren't even forty when you     stopped writing... I've never     understood why you gave it up.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: It's a long story...
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: I have time.         Tell me. Please.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: If you'd shown up yesterday, or    last week... I'd have said no and    sent you on your way. But here    you are, today of all days.    Somehow... it seems like the right    time for me to finally tell this    story...
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: It begins many years ago... when    I was eighteen... and the worst    thing that could happen to a young    man happened to me... my father    died...
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: We were very close, my father and    I. Partly because we'd lost my    mother five years earlier...
I know.        I read a biography about you.
It said you stopped writing so you    could conduct scientific    research... ?
It's not... quite that simple...

You see, right before my father    died, I was working on a short    story. I don't remember what it    was about... but I do know that I    was taking it very seriously. I    worked on it night and day for    weeks... but I couldn't seem to    make any headway, and it was    making me miserable.
I suppose my father thought I    needed to take a break, because he    insisted I come to the Gamma    Quadrant with him to watch the    wormhole undergo what they call a    subspace inversion...
scene: 6    INT.  DEEP SPACE NINE - JAKE'S BEDROOM (PRESENT)

quote: Of course what he didn't realize    was that I could hide away on the    Defiant just as easily as I    could on the station...
Yeah.
Come on, Jake. This only happens    once every fifty years. You'll    never forgive yourself if you miss    it.
I'll be right there.
You said that ten minutes ago.
I just want to get this paragraph    right.
I thought you were going to put    that aside for a while.
I tried, but it's all I can think    about.

I'm no writer, but if I were, it    seems to me that I'd want to poke    my head up once in a while and    take a look around... see what's    going on.        It's life, Jake; you can miss it    if you don't open your eyes.
What do you say we go up to the    bridge, watch the wormhole do its    thing, then I'll read what you've    got and we can talk about it.        Deal?
Deal.
Sisko to Bridge. What happened?
The wormhole's gravimetric field    is surging...
Pull us back to a safe distance.
I'm on it, Benjamin. But we've    got another problem. Power output    from the warp core just jumped off    the scale.
Sisko to Engineering.         Engineering, report.
Dax, I'm going to find out what's    happening down there.        Stay here.
Most of the time, I knew enough to    do what my father told me... but    that day, for some reason, I    didn't...
Sisko to Sickbay, I need a medical    team down here right away.
Dax to Sisko, the warp coils are    locked into a feedback loop...    You've got to realign them or the    core's going to blow...
I'm on it.
Jake, get me an interphasic    compensator.
Warning. Warp core breach in    fifty seconds.
Dax, you'd better stand by to    eject the core.
We can't. The ejection system is    off-line.
Where's that compensator?
It's not here... got it.
Warning. Warp core breach in    thirty seconds.
I'm going to try shunting the    excess power out through the    deflector array.
Just a little more...
There...
No!
He was gone...
I'm not sure I could ever get over    losing someone like that, right in    front of my eyes...
People do. Time passes, they    realize that the person they lost    is really gone... and they heal.
Is that what happened to you?
No... I suppose not.
There was a memorial service    aboard the station.
People came forward and talked    about my father, what they    remembered most about him... why    they would miss him...
I didn't step forward... I    couldn't... I felt that no matter    what I said about him, I'd be    leaving so much more out... and    that didn't seem right...
Everyone went out of their way to    look after me, especially Dax.    She was my father's closest    friend, and I guess she felt    responsible for me.         After a few months...
... things started returning to    normal... for everyone else, that    is...
I tried to put on a brave face...    I didn't want people worrying    about me more than they already    were...
I'm almost done. We have    Holosuite Three for half an hour.
Great...
Nog, get down to the storeroom and    bring up five kegs of Takarian mead.
Yes, Uncle.
Sorry, it looks like we're going    to lose our holosuite reservation.
You know, Nog, things seem to be    slowing down a bit.
I'll have someone else bring up    the kegs. You and Jake go have    some fun.
(looking around at the     hopping crowd)    Are you sure?
Go. Now. Before I change my    mind.
Next time we go ion surfing,    remind me to keep clear of those    whip curls.
I don't know if I really want to   try it again...
You know, Jake... I'm going to be    gone soon... we probably won't see    each other for a while.
I know...
So... what are your plans?
I was thinking about taking that    deferred admission and going to    Pennington in the fall...
That'd be great. We'd both be on    Earth.
But maybe I'll just stick around    here... I haven't decided yet.
It's late... I think I'll turn    in...
Okay...
Jake... ?
Dad... ?
What... what happened... ?

I told Dax about what'd    happened... how it felt so    real... not like a dream at all...         -- and she very kindly obliged me    and did a thorough scan of my    room. I felt vaguely    ridiculous... like a child    insisting his parents check under    his bed for monsters.
She said it was probably just a    nightmare, and I did my best to    put the whole episode out of my mind.
I puttered around the station for    the next eight or nine months.    Nog was off at Starfleet...

-- my stories stubbornly refused    to write themselves... so I    filled my time playing dom-jot...   and trying not to think about how    alone I felt...        Dax and the others were worried    about me... but before long, they    had bigger things to worry about.
Tensions with the Klingons were    continuing to rise...

My father was a kind of religious    figure to the Bajoran people, and    when he died, they took it as a    sign from the Prophets that the    Federation wouldn't be able to    protect them from the Klingons.    Eventually, Bajor entered into a    mutual defense pact with the    Cardassians, and the Klingons    didn't like that at all.
There are plenty of seats on the    transport, and there's another one    leaving in just two hours. That's    it, move along... thank you.
The station's civilian population    was leaving en masse... they knew    that if war broke out against the    Klingons, Deep Space Nine was    going to be on the front line.
Jake, where are you going... ?
I thought I'd watch the ships    leaving from one of the upper    pylons...
You should be on one of those    ships.
I don't have to go, do I?
This is a voluntary resettlement,    not an evacuation.
But it would be prudent for you to    leave at this time.
I suppose I wasn't feeling very    prudent that day... because I    ignored their advice...
Jake... ?
I want to talk to you about    something.
I spoke with your grandfather...   he told me he'd asked you to come    live with him.
Even if this sector weren't on the    brink of war, I'd still like to    see you leave the station.
I'm not going anywhere.
Jake... if I wanted to, I could   order you to go.
Please don't make me leave. Not    yet. This is my home.
When Dad and I came here, this    place was just an abandoned shell;    he turned it into something.        Everywhere I look... it's like I'm    seeing a part of him.
If I leave...        I won't have anything left of    him...
All right, stay a while longer if    you want. But promise me that    when the time comes and I tell you    to go, you'll do it.
Dad... ?
It wasn't until I actually touched    him that I knew... this wasn't a    dream...

But there was no time    It looks like his temporal  for reunions -- something   signature has been altered  was wrong. I didn't    somehow... understand everything  they were saying, but      DAX Dax and the others seemed     to think that the    The energy discharge... accident had somehow  knocked my father's       O'BRIEN "temporal signature" out   It must've interacted with of phase...     the graviton pulse.

Dax and the others seemed     to think that the    The energy discharge... accident had somehow  knocked my father's       O'BRIEN "temporal signature" out   It must've interacted with of phase...     the graviton pulse.
"temporal signature" out   It must've interacted with of phase...     the graviton pulse.
And altered his temporal       signature.
signature.
Then he must've phase       shifted into subspace...
shifted into subspace...
Benjamin, what's the last thing        you remember... ?
you remember... ?
I was in Engineering... on the        Defiant... feels like a few        minutes ago...

character: I was in Engineering... on the
quote: Defiant... feels like a few        minutes ago...
minutes ago...
Dad, it's been over a year since    the accident.
A year... how can that be?
We think that the warp core    discharge pulled you into    subspace. If we're right, that    would explain why you didn't    experience the passage of time...
According to these readings,    unless we can find a way to re-   align your temporal signature,    you'll be pulled back into    subspace within a few minutes.
Maybe we can set up some sort of    containment field...
Hey...        They'll have me fixed up in no    time...
How are you doing?
It's all right... everything's    going to be all right...
I thought it was a dream...
What was?
When I saw you in my quarters...    I should've known you were still    alive... I should've felt it...
It's not your fault, Jake. I'm    here now... that's what matters.
We're losing him --
Look at me. I need to know that    you're going to be all right.
Chief, I need that containment    field now...
Field active...
Jake...
It's not working, Chief...
Dad...
I'm going to try locking onto him    with the transporter...
Don't leave me...

I didn't think anything could be   worse than losing him that first    time on the Defiant... until I was    standing there staring down at    that empty bed... knowing that he    was alive, trapped somewhere that    existed outside time...
I... can't imagine what that   must've been like for you...
What's wrong...
Can I get you something... ?
No... nothing.
Telling me all this is hard for   you.  Maybe I should come back   some other time?
No... there won't be another time.
You see... I'm dying...
I've upset you... you have to    understand, when a man my age says    he's dying, he's just admitting to    the inevitable...
Besides, we older people sometimes    like to remind everyone that they    should pay special attention to    us...
If that's what you're up to you    shouldn't have bothered. You have    my attention already.
You're a good listener... that's    important in a writer.
I'm not a writer yet.
You make it sound like you're    waiting for something to happen    that'll turn you into one.
I'm not waiting.       I'm doing a lot of reading.
You know, to see how it's done.    And I'm still trying to figure out    what it is I want to write about.
I see...
What happened? With your father,    I mean. Did you ever see him    again?

For the next few months Dax and    O'Brien worked to find a way to    locate him. They considered    trying to recreate the accident,    but that was impossible since the    wormhole wasn't going to undergo    another inversion for decades.    Eventually the situation with the    Klingons came to a head, and the    Federation decided to turn over    control of the station to the    Klingon Empire.
There was nothing I could do. I    had to leave my home of five    years...
And give up whatever hope there    was of seeing my father again...
I'm sorry...
Did the Klingons ever contact    Starfleet to say that your father    had reappeared?
No...

I was left with no choice but to    try to get on with my life.  I    went to Earth, drifted around for    a few years, and eventually ended    up studying writing at the    Pennington school. After I    graduated, I settled here in    Louisiana so I could be near my    grandfather. He had a restaurant    in the French Quarter, you know.
I've been there. It's still    called "Sisko's."  And on the wall    there's a copy of the letter your    publisher sent you when he    accepted your first novel.
Grandpa was always showing off his    "famous" grandson. He was every    bit as proud of me as my father    would've been.
You wrote "Anslem" in this house,    didn't you?

At that desk over there.        It came out to generally favorable    reviews... and little by little,    I began to think less and less    about the past. Eventually I met    a woman, fell in love, and    married... for a while, this house    was a happy one...
I'm back...
Korena...
Nog, I didn't realize you were    here already... I was trying to   finish a painting before the light    changed and I guess the time got    away from me.
It's good to see you...
You too.       Did you start the grill... ?
What are we having?
Blackened redfish... fresh from    the bayou.
Fish... when these woods are    crawling with perfectly good    slugs?
I suppose you're going to ask me    to chew your food for you... ?
I have to admit I've been more    popular with women since I stopped    asking them to do that.
I tried to tell you that twenty years    ago.
I'm a slow learner...
I'm going to get some champagne.
I'm glad you're here, Nog...
I see you've got another pip on    your collar. You keep this up    you'll make captain by the time    you're forty.
Last time we talked you mentioned    you might be heading to the    Bajoran Sector.

The Klingons agreed to let    Starfleet send an expedition    through the wormhole... they said    it was in the spirit of scientific    exchange, but I think they were    happy to have us test the waters    in the Gamma Quadrant after all    these years -- find out how the    Dominion would react to ships    coming through.
Did you see the station?
I'm sorry to say it's looking a    little run down these days.
But you'll never guess who's still    there.
Not... your father?

No, he and my Uncle left years    ago. Quark finally got that    little moon he was always talking    about, and my father, as usual, is    making sure it doesn't fall out of    orbit... But Morn is still    there... running the bar.
Talking his customers' ears off    and drinking himself out of    business, I'll bet.
Well... why don't we get to the    point of today's little    celebration...

(raises his champagne    glass in a toast)   To my dear friend Jake Sisko,   winner of this year's Betar prize   for his "Collected Stories." May   the years continue to be good to   you, may your muse...        -- continue to inspire you...
And may someone make a holo-   program out of one of your stories    so you can start raking in the    latinum!
Are you all right? Do you want me    to call a doctor?
No.
I'll be fine...
You should rest...
No... you came a long way to find    out why I stopped writing, and you    deserve an answer...
Later that night, after Nog had    left...
I stayed up working. My new novel    was going well, and when it's    going well you don't want to    stop...
Coming to bed?
I'm not tired.
Neither am I.
I want to ask you something...         How would you feel about designing    the cover of my new book?
Do you mean it?
What is it?
Jake... ?
Did you get through?
I talked to someone at Starfleet   Science; they're going to get a   team here as soon as they can.
This is Korena... my wife.
Your wife...
I never thought I'd have the    pleasure of meeting you.
The pleasure's mine.         How long have you two been    married?
Seven years.
Do I...        -- have any grandchildren?
Not yet.
We were married in New Orleans, in    your father's restaurant.
He insisted. Just about everyone    came. Dax, Kira, O'Brien...
That must've been something...
I'm going to call Starfleet, see    what's taking so long.
Jake. They'll get here as    soon as they can. Talk to me. I've    missed so much. Let's not waste    what little time we have.
I have a feeling you might want to    see these... they're Jake's.
You did it. I always knew you    would...
Hey...
I'm sorry....
What for... ?
For giving up on you...
No one could've been expected to    hold out hope for this long.
I should've kept trying to find    you... instead I just went on with    my life...
And I'm proud of what you've    accomplished.
None of it matters. Not when I    know you're still lost out there...
Of course it matters... you have    a career, a wife.        And don't think that just because    I'm not around much I don't want    grandchildren.
Within a few seconds, he was gone    again...
I... don't know what to say...

You don't need to say anything.    Just listen, because there isn't    much time, and there's still so    much left for me to tell you.         I consulted with Dax and we    realized that the accident must've    created some sort of subspace link    between my father and me.
That's why he always appeared    somewhere near you; even if you    were hundreds of light years from    where the accident happened.

We also realized there was a    pattern to his appearances; they    were governed by fluctuations in    the wormhole's subspace field.    Dax's calculations showed that the    next time he appeared, I'd be an    old man.        I decided to put aside my novel    and try to find a way to help him.    And so, at the age of thirty-   seven, I went back to school and    started studying subspace    mechanics.

At first Korena was very    patient... she supported what I    was trying to do. But I got so    caught up in my work I didn't    notice I was losing her. By the    time I became a graduate student,    we weren't living together    anymore. And by the time I    entered my doctoral program,    it was over between us.
But I pressed on with what I was    doing... And one day, years later,    it hit me.        I figured out a way to recreate    the accident.
It'd been almost fifty years, and    the wormhole would soon be    undergoing another inversion.    There was only one other thing I    needed.
The Defiant... Nog was a Captain   by then, and he managed to call in   a few favors at Starfleet Command   and got it pulled out of   mothballs...
Worf threw his weight around with    the Klingon High Council, and they    gave us permission to enter the    Bajoran system.
Take us out of warp...
I think I remember how to do    that...
I haven't worked a two-dimensional    control panel in a long time...    how did we manage... ?
We always seemed to muddle through    somehow...
Look...
Maybe after we've got Captain   Sisko back, we should all drop by   Morn's for a drink...
I'd designed a subspace flux    isolator...
And we set it up in Engineering.
Are you ready over there, Dax... ?
As ready as I'll ever be,    considering the replicators were    just about the only things still    working when we came aboard.
It's a lucky thing too... These    days, Dax isn't much good to    anybody without a cup of coffee in    her hand.
It's the only thing that kept me    awake while you prattled on about    your latest paper, or your new    backhand, or your kid's science    projects...
We're picking up temporal    distortions in the subspace    field...
The wormhole's beginning to   invert...
According to our readings it's    going to kick out a gravimetric    wave like the one that almost    destroyed the Defiant last time...
Don't worry... I've modulated the    shields to channel the wave's    energy into this apparatus.
Once subspace begins to fragment,    we'll try to locate the captain.
Since the accident created a    subspace link between him and    Jake, we'll have a path of "bread    crumbs" to follow...
I'd better get back to the bridge.       Good luck...
The wormhole wouldn't undergo   another inversion for decades, so   this was my only chance...
Subspace field fragmentation is    beginning...
It's working...
I think I've located the    captain's signature...
Something's happening... I'm    losing him...
We're losing them both... they're    being pulled into subspace...
Jake... how long has it been... ?
Fourteen years...
What is this place... ?
I don't know...
We could be inside some sort of   subspace fragment...
Sisko to Dax...        Can you read me?
I brought the Defiant back to the    wormhole... we're trying to rescue    you...        Dax, if you can hear me, try to    lock onto my signal...
Look at you... you're older than    I am...
Dammit. Why can't they lock on to    us?

Jake, they're doing everything    they can. There's nothing we can    do from here.       It's been so long. I need to know    what I've missed.        What about those grandchildren we    talked about?
Korena and I... we're not together    anymore. She left me...
I'm sorry...
I shouldn't have let her go... but    there was so much I had to do;    this has taken years of planning.
What about... your writing?
(slapping angrily at his    combadge)   Dax. Try boosting the carrier   amplitude... maybe you can...
Jake... what's happened to you... ?
This is the last chance I'll ever    have to help you...
No...
Listen to me... it's over... it's    not going to work...
It has to.
Let go, Jake. If not for yourself    then for me. You still have time    to make a good life for yourself.
Promise me you'll do that...    promise me.
I want you to see something. Go    over to my desk...
Go ahead...
It's a collection of new stories...
I decided to honor my father's    request and try to rebuild my    life... writing these stories was    the best way I knew to do that.
I want you to have a copy...
Let me get you one.
Can I have these, instead?
If you want, but they have    handwritten notes all over them.
I know... I want to study them...    so I can see the changes you made...
Because you want to be a writer    someday.
Can I ask why you haven't    published these?
I was still tinkering with the    last one just this morning.         Besides, if you publish    posthumously no one can ask you    for rewrites.
I was hoping to be able to finish    another two stories, but there    just wasn't enough time.
You keep saying that there's no    more time.

You see, Melanie... after the    attempt to rescue my father     failed, I spent months trying to     figure out what went wrong.     Eventually, I came to understand     the nature of what was happening     to him. It was as if he was    frozen in time at the moment of    the accident, and the link between    us was like an elastic cord.     Every so often, it would become    taut enough to yank him forward to    my time. But only for a few    minutes.

I realized that if my motion    through time came to a stop, the    cord would go slack, and he'd be    lost in subspace forever. But if    I could cut the cord when the link    was at its strongest... when we    were together, he'd return to the    moment of the accident.
Your father's coming here, isn't    he? Soon.
Yes...
You're going to cut the cord...    aren't you?
I want you to promise me    something.
Anything.
While you're... "studying" my    stories... poke your head up    every once in a while and take a    look around... see what's going    on.       It's life, Melanie...
And you can miss it if you don't    open your eyes...
Thank you... for everything...
It was a pleasure meeting you,    young lady.
Jake...

quote: I've been expecting you...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: I'm glad you're still in this    house... You seemed happy here...        And this... I can't tell you how    good it makes me feel to see you    got back to writing...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Jake... what is it... ?
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Look at the dedication...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: "To my Father, who's coming home... "         Thank you... but... I don't    understand...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: It was me. It was me all along.    I've been dragging you through    time like an anchor... and now    it's time to cut you loose...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: What are you saying... ?
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: It won't be long now...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Jake... no...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: When I die, you'll go back to    where this whole thing began...    you just have to remember to dodge    the energy discharge from the warp    core...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: You could still have so many years    left...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: No... we have to be together    when I die...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Jake... you didn't have to do    this... not for me...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: For you... and for the boy that I    was... he needs you more than you    know...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Don't you see? We're going to get    a second chance...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Jake... my sweet boy...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: You okay?
How'd you know that was coming... ?
I guess... we were just lucky this   time...
Dad, are you all right?
I am now, Jake... I am now...
